awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Characterization of Epigenetic Factors and their Regulatory Roles in Modulating Transposable Elements, Plant Immunity and Transgenerational Inheritance
awd_abstract_narration:
Transposable elements (TEs), also known as jumping genes, comprise a major portion of eukaryotic genomes, although their functional contribution is still one of biology's big mysteries. Due to the potentially mutagenic nature of their transposition activity, it has been assumed that TEs are heavily suppressed, if not completely silenced, predominantly through epigenetic mechanisms, i.e., non-inheritable chemical modifications introduced into chromosomes. The researchers' analyses suggest, however, that TEs are rapidly and transiently derepressed in response to pathogen infection. Based on these findings, it is hypothesized that TEs play important roles in transcriptional reprogramming/activation in response to biotic stress and that their activity leads to phenotypic plasticity and stress adaptation. For the host plant, the proposed ability of TEs to transduce environmental challenges into epigenetic modifications that lead to stable genetic changes should confer significant evolutionary advantages. Therefore, elucidating the molecular mechanisms through which stress adaptation is mediated by epigenetic changes and clarifying their relationship to TE activation following biotic stress will be tremendously valuable for developing new traits in the plant breeding industry. The proposed research also will allow undergraduate students, as well as high school students and their teachers, to investigate solutions to a real-world problem via experimentation using high-throughput assays that will provide a robust dataset after a limited training period. The results of these analyses will be presented at local, state and national science fairs.

The researchers'  analysis of genome-wide chromatin accessibility suggests that the promoters and/or 5' proximal regions of many defense genes contain TEs that display heightened and dynamic chromatin accessibility in Arabidopsis after pathogen infection. These TE-associated chromatin regions exhibit infection-induced dynamic interactions with MORC1, a protein implicated in both RNA-dependent DNA methylation (RdDM) and immunity in plants. Given that i) TEs are suppressed mostly by RdDM, ii) pathogen infection induces a burst of TE expression, and iii) both TE transcription and mobility are modulated by the RdDM pathway, epigenetic factors involved in RdDM will be investigated to test the role(s) of RdDM and TEs in the induction of defense genes following pathogen infection. To this end, specific TEs and RdDM components will be silenced or knocked-out to monitor DNA methylation, chromatin accessibility and transcription levels for both targeted TEs and their proximal defense genes following infection. TEs' role in stress adaptation will also be examined by inducing biotic stress-induced TE transposition and determining if novel TE insertions confer stress-induced transcription of their proximal genes in subsequent generations. Altogether, this project seeks to significantly advance our understanding of the relationship between TEs and both immunity and stress adaptation.

por.por_cntn:
Successful defense responses in plants accompany a massive transcriptomic reprogramming, which involves significant epigenetic changes including those in chromatin topology. Our main goal was to obtain a deeper understanding of how epigenetic factors and their linked transposons regulate the expression of defense genes under biotic stress.

We employed a pathosystem consisting of Arabidopsis and Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato (Pst) to investigate defense genes with distinct levels of induction in response to avirulent and virulent Pst. In our multi-time-point transcriptome analysis, we detected significant gene expression changes just 6 hours after infection by avirulent Pst, contrasting with the absence of such changes by the virulent strains. To explore the role of an epigenetic molecule in preceding the transcriptional changes, we conducted deep sequencing of nuclear small RNAs (sRNAs) in Arabidopsis one hour after infection with Pst. Additionally, we performed RNA immunoprecipitation-seq to sequence nuclear sRNAs associated with the potential effectors AGO1 and AGO2. Both approaches identified a limited set of tRFs (tRNA fragments) that are avirulent Pst?-inducible and DCL1-dependent, suggesting their role in early defense responses. tRF31Asp2, which is 31 nucleotides long and originates from an Asp tRNA gene, was chosen for further investigations based on its highest induction among the tRFs identified. By utilizing biotin-labeled tRF31Asp2, we found that tRF31Asp2 binds to a specific sequence in the Gypsy superfamily of LTR-retrotransposons, as well as its homologous transposon-like sequences in defense genes. Interestingly, when we infiltrated tRF31Asp2 into Arabidopsis, we observed the activation of over 500 defense genes and protection for Arabidopsis against both Pst and aphids.

Growing evidence indicates that transposons have been co-opted for regulatory elements for hosts. Our Arabidopsis chromatin accessibility map under biotic stress scored by DNase I hypersensitive sites also revealed that significant changes are associated with transposons, further confirming the role of transposons and their associated epigenetic factors in plant immunity. We recently uncovered that tRFs are mobile, and that a key gene associated with systemic acquired resistance (SAR) plays a role in this tRF mobility. This intriguing observation suggests that SAR likely utilizes tRFs to facilitate communication between infected and uninfected leaves. We also attempted to characterize epigenetic factors in transgenerational immunity and failed to obtain any conlusion due to technical limitations. However, it has also been demonstrated that tRFs of the same length as tRF31Asp2 are implicated in transgenerational stress response in mice. This interesting discovery opens up the potential for our identified tRFs to also play a role in transgenerational immunity.

MORC1 is one of few proteins known to physically associate with a large number of plant immune components, including 12 resistance proteins. For its further characterization, we have investigated two MORC1 interacting proteins, MIP10 and MIP13; characterization of MIP10 by our collaborator Manosalva is still underway. MIP13 encodes MED9, a mediator complex component that interfaces with RNA polymerase II and transcriptional factors to reprogram transcriptional activities. We found that the interaction between MORC1 and MED9 is essential in curbing down defense genes and restoring photosynthesis to modulate fitness costs associated with biotic stress. It is known that prolonged defense responses can hinder growth and lead to reduced crop yields. Currently, we are investigating photosynthesis modulators PIF3 and PIF4, which play a role in suppressing photosynthetic activity during immune responses. This discovery on how the epigenetic factors contribute to balancing plant immunity and growth will soon be submited for publication.

We maintained our collaboration with San Marcos High School (SMHS), a local school that serves a minority population, for our outreach initiatives. We are proud to highlight some remarkable accomplishments resulting from this collaboration. One of the high school students co-authored our MPMI paper and received recognition at the international science fair. Another student conducted a live-imaging study to characterize mobile tRFs in Arabidopsis under biotic stress, which also advanced to the international science fair. We anticipate the publication of this project in a prestigious venue. Notably, prior to our collaborative efforts, the local school had not seen any students advance to the international science fair. Through our outreach program, we have nurtured budding young scientists in the community and increased the visibility of research activities at SMHS. This has also led to the creation of a research course and greater participation in original research projects at SMHS.

In summary, we identified a wide range of epigenetic contributions to plant immunity. We are excited to report the nobel role of tRFs in plant immunity, potentially acting as signaling molecules that traverse within plants. We envision that this outcome will lead the community to a groundbreaking area of investigation wherein these tRFs can be engineered to confer resistance traits. Currently, we have a pending patent application for utilizing tRFs as a biopesticide, and we are actively collaborating with agricultural companies to assess the efficacy of tRFs for protecting crop plants against diseases.
